title: Beating Old Age in Straight Sets
summary: At almost 79, I'm pushing my luck playing tennis. But I'm not built to sit still.. After one reaches 70 the ailments of age usually kick in, and you'll probably get worse at your favorite sport. The odd thing for me is: I'm almost 79 yet I'm a better tennis player than I was at 50.

title: 'Why We're Polarized' Review: Going to Extremes
summary: You don't need to shed your opinions to write convincingly about polarization in politics, but a little self-criticism might help.. Ezra Klein is a gifted political analyst, a hyperproductive and witty blogger, a fluent podcaster and television commentator, and the co-founder of Vox, the popular left-liberal "explanatory" news website. Mr. Klein is a lot of things. What he isn't is humble.

title: NeoGenomics Promotes Accounting Chief to CFO

title: A Bitter Impeachment Ends; Its Divisions May Live On
summary: The rancor between the GOP and Democrats may not be just an impediment for the rest of the year but for a long time to come. The stately dome of the U.S. Capitol has towered over many a dramatic scene since it was completed a century-and-a-half ago. Yet most recently, the dome has stood in silent witness to what feels like a lifetime's worth of drama packed into just a few weeks.

title: Judge Bars Secondary Exchange Founder From ACP Partners Fund
summary: A preliminary injunction against Nyppex founder Laurence Allen follows a fraud complaint brought against him in December. title: Merck to Spin Off Slow-Growth Products Into New Company
summary: Merck will spin off about 90 products, including cholesterol drug Zetia, into a new, publicly-traded company next year. title: Last Harvey Weinstein Accuser Testifies He Groped Her in Hotel
summary: The testimony of Lauren Young opened a window into a separate criminal case that Los Angeles prosecutors are bringing against the Hollywood producer. title: How Iowa Slipped Away From Joe Biden
summary: Former vice president now must convince donors and voters in other early states to stick with him in a fiercely competitive field. DES MOINES, Iowa-In the months leading up to the Iowa caucuses, Joe Biden suggested he could stake an early claim to the Democratic nomination with a victory.

title: SPF Is Essential When Skiing. So Are These Other Skin Products.
summary: On the slopes, your face can take a beating. Here's how to protect your skin before, during and after the sport. SCHUSSING DOWN the slopes can leave your skin invigorated-or, if you're not careful, chapped. Multiple elements victimize your complexion at once, said New York City dermatologist, founder of MMSkincare and skier Ellen Marmur. "Wind, sun, cold, heat and dryness at high altitude create the perfect situation for damage," she said. A 2003 Journal of the American Medical Association study found that sun intensity increases about 6% to 9% for every 1,000 feet of elevation, said Dr. Marmur, and sun reflection off the snow further ups your UV exposure. Which means you need more than a balaclava for protection. Here's what else to reach for to shield and heal.

title: Stop Skiing in Jeans. It's Not the 1970s Anymore.
summary: While denim daredevils ruled the slopes last century, today's skiers generally prefer high-tech snow pants. A brief history. PITY THE denim-wearing skier. As he pointed out, jeans are neither waterproof nor insulating. Those who brave the bluff in jeans are often inexperienced bunny-hill bumblers who don't know any better.

title: Coronavirus Hits Shipping as China Port Traffic Slides

title: 'Corrupt Motives' Charge Will Haunt Politics
summary: Democrats in Congress are late in embracing "The 'Corrupt Motives' Doctrine" as years ago federal judges established a precedent for divining President Trump's evil motives.. Democrats in Congress are late in embracing "The 'Corrupt Motives' Doctrine" (Review & Outlook, Jan. 30) as years ago federal judges established a precedent for divining President Trump's evil motives. Two U.S. District Court judges blocked Mr. Trump's executive order in early 2017 restricting travel to the U.S. from six countries that were plagued by terrorism because they believed the order was motivated by anti-Muslim bias. Although the executive order had only a stated secular and national security purpose, the judiciary's clairvoyants deemed it tainted by what Mr. Trump said on the campaign trail. There is good reason for Democratic presidential candidates to flirt with the idea of packing the Supreme Court with new, liberal justices who would also have psychic powers.

title: Touchdown Dancing Is a Sign of Our Times
summary: One can remember the coaches in the NFL and colleges trying very hard to squelch the ridiculous shows of unsportsmanlike conduct that started breaking out a number of decades ago.. Regarding Joseph Epstein's "A Good Sport is Hard to Find, Especially in the NFL" (op-ed, Feb. 1): One can remember the coaches in the NFL and colleges trying very hard to squelch the ridiculous shows of unsportsmanlike conduct that started breaking out a number of decades ago. But the press was working full steam to thwart the coaches' efforts. The cameras invariably sought out players doing the dances, etc., and dwelt on them for the entire little performance. The coaches finally quit fighting and went along.

title: Legislators and Regulators Failed in 2007
summary: Had the free market been permitted to operate unfettered by congressional interference, the problem wouldn't have occurred.. William A. Galston writes that "the global financial crisis [was] fed by the greed and recklessness of major financial institutions and the absence of effective government oversight" ("Liberal Democracy's Threats From Within," Politics & Ideas, Jan. 22). He is half right.

title: Playing Solitaire With All Those Old Business Cards
Five-Star Ski Snacks
summary: When you cook or make wine for a living, you're pickier than most about the bites you pack (or flask you fill) for a day on the slopes. A great deal of thought goes into what will take up valuable real estate in my backpack. If I find myself touring somewhere in Japan, there's nothing better than a couple onigiri, Japanese rice balls formed around myriad fillings. And that flask that always seems to be around usually has some Japanese whisky inside. Because, pairing."

title: Oscar Picks From the Journal's Joe Morgenstern
summary: Wall Street Journal critic Joe Morgenstern predicts who will win the top honors at Sunday's Academy Awards. Go figure. The theatrical exhibition business-meaning people getting out of the house and joining others they don't know to see a movie on a big screen in a dark room-is by every reliable metric in steady decline. Studios are disappearing like desiccated fronds on a palm tree. Yet last year yielded a bounty of fine films, leaving audiences feeling fulfilled and critics feeling obligated to do their annual rankings. Here are some of my thoughts on who deserves to win the top honors at the 92nd Academy Awards-and who could, should or will take home an Oscar.

title: A Portland Contemporary Brings Mexico Home
summary: Claudia Ochoa and Pedro Molina moved to Oregon thinking they might return to Mexico one day. Twenty years later, the couple built a $1.9 million home that mixes Pacific Northwest modernism with a Mexican aesthetic. Claudia Ochoa and Pedro Molina always thought they would end up back in Mexico. "It's home there," says Mr. Molina. Ms. Ochoa describes the Mexican city where they lived, Cuernavaca, as a land of "eternal spring," where the sun shone and she was always going to parties with her mom and her sisters at homes with beautiful backyards and swimming pools. But, as Ms. Ochoa says, "It's one thing what you plan, and another what happens."

title: How the Failure of Pets.com Spurred Julie Wainwright's RealReal Success
summary: The $1.5 billion company The RealReal's founder is changing the way we buy and sell luxury. Raised in South Bend, Indiana, by a pair of illustrators, Julie Wainwright, the founder and CEO of luxury consignment site The RealReal , recalls a childhood punctuated by creativity. She directed neighborhood plays, enlisting her mother as the costume designer. Her father, a co-founder of an advertising art firm, often cast her and her three siblings in his company's photo shoots. Such ingenuity served as a model for Wainwright, 62, as she later navigated a rough patch in her career. Following her turn two decades ago as CEO of Pets​.com-which became a high-profile victim of the early-2000s dot-com crash-her job prospects were "just horrible," says Wainwright. "I thought, I don't want to live my life like this. [I came] to the realization that I wasn't ever going to get a great job, and I'd have to create my own opportunities."

title: Three Artists at the Nexus of Fashion and Design
summary: Luke Edward Hall, Liselotte Watkins and Nigel Peake have made a career of fusing artistic backgrounds with fashionable clients. The Swedish-born artist Liselotte Watkins spent the first 20 years of her career as a fashion illustrator, drawing glamorous women for publications such as Vogue and Elle. She started to shift into different domains in 2008, when she and her husband moved to Milan and started a family. "Coming to Italy, where everything is so bright and sunny and strong, it just started things in my head," says Watkins, who began making cut-paper collages and painting colorful abstract figures on found ceramics. Now 48 and residing in Rome, she dips back into fashion occasionally, working with brands such as Prada, with whom she designed abstract face-print bags. Watkins has also created a collection with Miu Miu, prints for Marimekko and an installation at Valextra's Milan flagship. "I try to do one [collaboration] a year," Watkins says. "It is a combination of the challenge of the commission and the fact that being an artist is quite lonely. I do enjoy the feeling of teamwork." worldofwatkins.com

title: The Memes That Make or Break the Oscars
summary: Resume Subscription. How much do the Academy Awards matter for regular people? Some of that will be determined Sunday night by what the internet makes of the show's tiniest moments. It could come down to something as simple as a three-second shot of an outburst, eye roll or outfit mishap in the celebrity audience.

title: Carlyle Group Posts Narrower Quarterly Loss
summary: Private-equity firm posted net loss of $8.3 million, compared with loss of $10.1 million in comparable quarter last year. Carlyle Group Inc. reported a narrower loss for the fourth quarter as the firm lapped a big investment loss a year earlier.

title: M.B.A. Programs Rush to Add STEM Degrees
summary: Schools try to lure more foreign students with science, tech specialties offering longer U.S. visa stays. Business schools are racing to add concentrations in science, technology, engineering and math to their M.B.A. programs as they try to broaden their appeal to prospective students overseas who want to work in the U.S.

title: Irish Farmers Prepare for Brexit Season-and an Election
summary: Resume Subscription. DUBLIN-Ireland has avoided its Brexit nightmare of a U.K. border dotted with customs posts, but Britain's withdrawal from the European Union threatens to aggravate problems that could cost Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar his job this weekend.

title: Bombardier's Crisis Shows How Business Isn't All About Product
summary: The Canadian manufacturer bit off more than it could chew, and its turnaround could be more difficult than analysts expect. Former Ford and Chrysler executive Lee Iacocca once said that "when the product is right, you don't have to be a great marketer." Bombardier's downward spiral suggests otherwise.

title: Japan, Land of the Rising Shareholders
summary: Japanese companies are increasingly subject to tender offers as corporate governance improves. Japan's corporate-governance reforms are throwing up opportunities. The latest: an increase in tender offers for Japanese companies.

title: Coronavirus Spurs Rally in Chinese Bonds
summary: Investors are betting on slower growth and easier monetary policy. Long-term Chinese bond yields have hit their lowest level in more than three years, as investors bet the coronavirus epidemic will lead to even slower growth and easier monetary policy.

title: Where Computing Is Headed-Beyond Quantum
summary: Startups are coming up with new ways to make computer chips and store huge amounts of data in DNA. BOSTON-Engineers working at a startup near touristy Faneuil Hall Marketplace are building chips that use laser beams instead of electrical signals to run artificial-intelligence applications 10 times faster than today's most advanced AI computer chips, using one-tenth of the energy.

title: Trump Touts Economy, Ignores Impeachment in State of the Union Speech
summary: One day after the Iowa caucuses and one day before his expected acquittal in the Senate, the president outlines his 2020 agenda. WASHINGTON-With his anticipated acquittal in his impeachment trial a day away, President Trump used his annual State of the Union address Tuesday to paint an optimistic picture of the country's future and tout the strong economy nine months before Election Day.

title: Buttigieg, Sanders Take Lead in Iowa
summary: Muddled reporting of the first contest brings little clarity to the Democratic presidential race. DES MOINES, Iowa-After a day of confusion and recriminations over a technical mishap that snarled the vote count, the first wave of delayed results from Iowa's presidential caucuses showed Pete Buttigieg and Sen. Bernie Sanders at the top of the Democratic pack.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Kirk Douglas, Chiseled Actor From Hollywood's Golden Age, Has Died
summary: A legacy of commanding roles, philanthropy and taking on McCarthyism and the Hollywood blacklist. Kirk Douglas, a son of Russian immigrants who rose to play Spartacus and other legendary roles during Hollywood's Golden Era, died Wednesday. He was 103.

title: Enterprise-Software M&A Deals Show Slowdown
summary: Deals are expected to pick up as interest in AI grows, analysts say. Large companies bought fewer enterprise-software firms in the second half of last year, easing up on a six-year spending spree for makers of cloud-based applications, artificial intelligence and other technologies, according to technology-market advisory firm Hampleton Partners.

title: Top Takeaways From Trump's State of the Union
summary: Economy and partisan divides feature prominently at event, impeachment doesn't. President Trump offered up plenty of greatest hits and some surprise flourishes for his third State of the Union address.

title: Cruise Passengers Quarantined on Board After Coronavirus Detected
summary: About 3,700 passengers and crew likely to remain on Diamond Princess for two weeks, Japan says. TOKYO-Japan said Wednesday that 10 people on a cruise ship with about 3,700 passengers and crew aboard tested positive for the novel coronavirus, and the health minister said everyone is likely to be kept on the ship for two weeks.

title: Full Text of President Trump's 2020 State of the Union Speech
summary: The president's speech, as released by the White House. Here is President Trump's State of the Union address as prepared for delivery and released by the White House.

title: Trump Impeachment Agonistes
summary: He addresses Congress on the eve of acquittal as his approval rating rises.. Donald Trump delivered his third State of the Union address Tuesday night in one of the most paradoxical political scenes in memory. The President stood before the House Speaker who recently impeached him, and a day before the Senate will acquit him as his approval rating rises.

title: NYSE Owner Makes Offer to Buy eBay
summary: A deal could value the online marketplace at more than $30 billion. The owner of the New York Stock Exchange has made a takeover offer for eBay Inc. that could value the sprawling online marketplace at more than $30 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Argentina Province Vows to Repay Debt After Talks Fail
summary: Key creditor rejects effort by Buenos Aires to delay repayment of $250 million bond issue. Argentina's Buenos Aires province said it would make a $250 million bond payment after failing to reach a deal with enough creditors to accept a delay, surprising investors who feared the province's leftist governor would force a messy default if no agreement was reached.

title: Virus Cases Cross 24,000; First Hong Kong Victim Dies
summary: Macau to close casinos for two weeks; China injects more cash into banking system.

title: Tally-by-App Experiment Fails in Iowa
summary: Faulty kickoff leads Democratic candidates to express frustration. Glitches to a mobile app and a backup phone-in plan for reporting results in Iowa's Democratic presidential caucuses delayed the outcome and heightened concerns about the integrity of the voting process in the 2020 elections.

title: Match Posts Higher Profit Boosted by Tinder, Affirms Revenue Projections
summary: Dating-services provider expects Tinder to have an increase in revenue comparable to 2019's. Match Group Inc. said full-year revenue topped $2 billion, fueled by growth in Tinder, and affirmed its revenue outlook for mid- to high-teen growth.

title: California Early Voters Draw Campaigns' Attention
summary: Ballots started going out this week ahead of the March 3 primary. LOS ANGELES-Voting in the nation's most populous and delegate-rich state has already started, even though California's primary isn't officially for a month, forcing Democratic presidential campaigns to turn attention toward it immediately after the Iowa caucus.

title: The Iowa Caucus Fiasco
summary: It could help Bernie Sanders and is a blow to political legitimacy.. There's no shortage of mordant fun to be had at the expense of the Democratic National Committee and Iowa Democratic Party after the fiasco of the inaugural 2020 presidential contest, which has yet to yield definitive results apparently as a result of coding errors in a tabulation app created by party insiders. The college of cardinals at least lets the world know with white or black smoke how the vote for pope is going.

title: Person Suspected of Coronavirus Case in New York City Tests Negative
summary: Seventeen New Yorkers in all have been tested, so far there have been no confirmed cases of coronavirus. A traveler who had been in China and was suspected of possibly having the coronavirus, has tested negative for the deadly disease, New York City health officials said Tuesday night.

title: Forever 21 Bankruptcy Sale Dashes Creditor Hopes
summary: Simon Property Group CEO said he is hopeful the retailer can be turned around. The judge presiding over Forever 21 Inc.'s bankruptcy approved an $81 million opening bid for the fast-fashion retailer's assets that has vendors fearful of taking heavy losses.

title: Collins Will Vote to Acquit Trump
summary: Maine lawmaker joins a few other GOP senators who are critical of president's effort in Ukraine, but who say it doesn't justify his ouster. WASHINGTON-Sen. Susan Collins said President Trump's efforts to press Ukraine to open an investigation into a Democratic presidential candidate were "improper and demonstrated poor judgment" but didn't warrant forcing him from office, joining a handful of Republican lawmakers who have criticized his actions while arguing they aren't impeachable.

title: Snap Adds Users, Though Guidance Disappoints
summary: Daily user base of the messaging app rises to 218 million, surpassing expectations. Snap Inc. reported quarterly growth in users and revenue, indicating the company is managing to carve out a larger role for its messaging app even in the face of strong competition.

title: Best Buy Says CEO Will Stay in Her Job
summary: Retailer concludes probe into allegations Corie Barry had inappropriate relationship. Best Buy Co. said it has concluded a board-led investigation into Chief Executive Corie Barry and has decided to keep her in her role atop the electronics retailer.

title: Iowa Voters Younger, More Diverse Than Leading Democratic Candidates
summary: Media exploits state Democratic party's debacle to take shots at Hawkeye electorate.. The Iowa Democratic Party may or may not have announced the winner of its presidential caucus, given that the party has released only partial results. Regardless, questions will continue about the political organization's handling of the event. And Democratic officials aren't the only ones who should be embarrassed. The party's reporting problems have somehow inspired much of the media to once again express its obsession with identity politics.

title: Trump Says War With Iran Was 'Closer Than You Thought'
summary: During lunch with TV anchors, president also says he will award Medal of Freedom to Rush Limbaugh. WASHINGTON-President Trump said war with Iran was "closer than you thought" and that he plans to award the Presidential Medal of Freedom to conservative talk-show host Rush Limbaugh, in remarks made during a nearly two-hour lunch with television anchors at the White House on Tuesday, according to people familiar with the conversation.

title: Britain's Largest Companies Fail to Boost Diversity on Boards, Regulator Finds
summary: A majority of big U.K. companies didn't have goals for ethnic diversity in the boardroom in 2019. Britain's largest companies rarely set targets for ethnic diversity on boards and fail to report on the issue, amplifying calls by the U.K. 's audit and accounting regulator to increase efforts to promote ethnic diversity.
